turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- 47, Ernest Triplett, Petitioner, versus the State of Iowa.
Mr. Tacy.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Chief Justice Warren, Honorable Justices of this Court, may it please the Court.
This seemed to the petitioner to be a case where in the factual situation is infinitely more important than the legal situation.
In other words, the petitioner does not propose to spend a great deal of time on the legal questions involved here unless something new is raised by the respondent concerning the law.

I think it's conceded by both sides that this Court has the right in certiorari to review de novo the entire proceedings in a state court in a criminal case and to determine and make an independent determination as to whether the Fourteenth Amendment has been violated in due process of law, denied to the accused.
The -- without going to an extended argument now about the law, the recent decisions and the past decisions going back many years indicate that there should be no question about this proposition.
And now, to the facts of this case.
On August 31st, 1954, a little boy by the name of Jimmy Bremmers disappeared from his home, Sioux City, Iowa.
And about 29 days later, his body was found after extended search in a pasture about 6 miles from Sioux City out on a winding country road.

It happened at this time that Mr. Ernest Triplett who is the petitioner in this case was soliciting music lessons from parents in the vicinity where Jimmy Bremmers lived on the night he disappeared and on other occasions.
Now, a neighbor out in that vicinity called the Police Department in Sioux City and said there was a music salesman out here soliciting music lessons the night Jimmy disappeared.
And on that suspicion alone, Ernest Triplett was requested or his employer was requested to have Mr. Triplett wait for the police because they want to question him.
Now, this request for Mr. Triplett to wait at his employer's office, the Flood Music Company in Sioux City for the police came in about 9:30.
Mr. Flood testified as he didn't appear nervous at all.
He said, “Yes, I'll wait for them.”
He waited for them until 1:30 in the afternoon, went out and got his lunch and came back.
And then about 1:30 in the afternoon, they came to get him.

And Detective Dennison and Matousec, Sioux City Police, took him into custody where as the record shows here, he was detained without a warrant for a total of 20 or 21 days by the police and that interval of detention was interrupted twice by sending him down to the state hospital for mental treatment at Cherokee, Iowa near Sioux City.
Now, the first instance he was sent down there by the request, he says detective -- one of the detectives in Sioux City and that was on September 15th, 1954.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Does the record show whether he had any prior medical history before this?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: He had none and no record of any felonies.
His record was clear as to any felony or any mental trouble.
Then after he --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why do you say it is felony?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: What is it?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you emphasize felony?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Well, I say that but no record of any -- of any --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean any crime or offense or --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Oh, I -- I believe --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I don't know what you were --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Might have been that he would -- had been arrested for some minor offense like being drunk or something like that, but no, no major crime.
No sex crime.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I was just trying to find out what --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: No sex crime.
No -- no other felony.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, what -- what was he sent in the institution before, for treatment or for diagnosis?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Well, the -- the officers said that he was sent down there for -- first, for treatment at his request.
However, he --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Right there, as treatment for what?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Well, they said that -- that he should -- that it was a treatment for an old case of syphilis.
Now, he denies that that he requested that.
He says the officer has requested it and made out the application for him and he signed it.
Be that as it may, he was brought back from the institution later.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) you said he went to a mental institution?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: For treatment for (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Well, that's -- that's what the record shows.
He says he went down there because he could rest better on the beds down there, he thought, than on the steel mattress, steel mesh in the jail of Sioux City.
Now, the question here -- the whole question here is whether this confession which was obtained and I want to make this a little bit short now at the present time.
This confession was obtained when he was taken to the mental hospital for the second time.

Now, after he was been jailed and questioned practically everyday for 20 days in the Sioux City Jail without being taken before a magistrate and there was one in the same building down the hall, the detectives admit that they questioned him everyday.
And when asked that when he reiterated over and over that he wasn't guilty, he wouldn't take no for an answer, and they said, “No.”
And the defendant testified, the accused testified.
That after he reached a certain point, that he didn't deny anything further, he -- and this is his language -- and showed you the character of the education or lack of the man.
He testifies there wasn't no use to deny nothing.
“You tell him and they would turn right around and shove it back in your mouth.”
That's his language in the record here, both in the briefs and in the -- in the record itself.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible) once does a man is confined, going on (Inaudible) free to walkout.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Oh, he was confined.
And the record shows he was under custody -- the custody of the police all the time.
I brought that out very carefully.
It's in the record, sir, that he -- he never at any time could leave.
That's admitted in the record.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did he -- was he offered -- was he told of his right to counsel and did either he or his -- his family endeavor to get counsel for him, do you know?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: No, he was a long ways from his family, it seemed.
He had a brother in Oregon who is a preacher but he wasn't out there.
And he testifies he was trying to earn enough money in the music solicitation business to go up where his brother was.
But now, he was visited.
We'll, get this now.
He was visited after he was 29 days either in police custody, 20 days and in the hospital a part of the time.
He was approached by Stanley Corbett who was then the President of the Sioux City Bar Association and Stanley Corbett asked him if he wanted a lawyer.
And his reply was that he wasn't guilty of anything.He didn't know that he wanted a lawyer.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: That's why I ask you the questions.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: I understood Mr. Corbett testified, and he went to see this (Inaudible) that he -- that he told him, all through that that was held against his will.
The department of police solved the murder.
That's why I'm asking the question.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: That is what Mr. Corbett testified to.
Mr. Triplett testified he didn't, remember that.
But also, Mr. Triplett testified the reason he didn't want to get out on the street now was that the -- a detective --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, he -- he, the accused, took --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He didn't want to get out on the street.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Well, the reason why he said that Mr. -- a detective in Sioux City, the record will show his name, told him that it would not be good for him to get out on the street and let the public get a hold of him because what they want to do to you.
Now, that's in the record and it is uncontradicted.
And the detective who is supposed to have told him that was in the courtroom and so was the prosecutor and it isn't denied in the record.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Well, is that consistent with that he is being detained against his will.
The -- that implies to me he was free to get out on the street but they didn't (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: No, the -- no, the -- Your Honor.

The implication there is that this detective that told him it wouldn't be safe for him on the street and the only thing that Stanley Corbett a lawyer, he was suggesting, was whether he wanted a lawyer.
Now, he wasn't advised to his rights to a lawyer and, Your -- Your Honor, I take -- we take this position.
Those men are not in position to set themselves up as a magistrate and decide whether this man wants a lawyer or not.
They're holding him there against the Iowa statute which is similar to the statutes of other states that they must take him before a magistrate without unnecessary delay and they're not doing that.
They're holding him there.
Now, he -- he testifies that he was afraid there.
That is that Mr. -- the detective had told him what would happen if he got on the street.
Now, here's something significant, Your Honor.
You'll find all through the record, in the -- in the brief and argument quoting the record that this man was not free to go.
He was always under police custody and was under arrest without a warrant all this time.
He was not free to go.
You will find that in the record.
And when this confession was taken, here was the circumstance.
Stanley Corbett visited him on October the 1st.
Then, according to the respondent's version of the defendant's testimony, he was then taken to the state mental hospital.
Then, now here's what happened after Stanley Corbett offered legal help.
The man was taken to the Commission on Insanity in Sioux City and committed to the state mental hospital again, and only three days elapsed before they got this confession from him.
And when this confession which is the gist of this case, whether it was voluntary or not, is the gist of this case, this confession was taken from him.

Now, on the 6th of October -- so between the 1st of October and the 5th of October, they took him to Sioux City and having him committed to Cherokee again where the lawyer couldn't have done anything if he'd wanted to.

And on the 6th of October now, five days after Stanley Corbett offered to help; his confession was gotten from him by chief of -- not chief detective but rather the psychiatrist within the -- the same hospital by the name of Dr.Azordegan.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Tacy, may I ask whether the -- the stenographic record is close as the circumstances of -- under which Mr. Corbett made this offer or --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: He'd --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- proposed having all we have in the record that I have before me, is that several lawyers would be glad to offer their services.
How did that -- does the record, the stenographic record show how he came to make this visit and make such an offer?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes, sir.
It -- according --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That may there -- that may there shed some light on what this (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: According to Mr. Corbett's testimony --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He was President of the Bar Association --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: He was the president of the local bar association and some of the bars suggested that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, but how did that come about?
That isn't a normal thing unless it's normal in Iowa?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: It isn't normal in Iowa.
It is --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well now, how did that come about?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: I -- I do not know, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And the record doesn't shed any light?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: The record doesn't show.
He just went and asked him if he wanted a lawyer and said some of the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There must have been some antecedent something to stimulate the persons of the bar association to say --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Well, he said some of the other lawyer had suggested.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If you want to get habeas corpus, there are members of the bar ready to serve you.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It pleases to read it but it --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- it also a stirs inquiry.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: We might also inquire, Your Honor, why Mr. Corbett didn't insist on having him arraigned when he'd already been held 29 days without arraignment at that time if he was there to protect him.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: We'll, I -- I'd like to ask because I'm interested in that.
We need to know all the facts.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The statement of counsel for the State is that Mr. Corbett wanted the presence of bar association, told him he was -- and wanted to find out if he's being held against his will, and if so, they want to offer service but they couldn't have any right to keep him.
Is that what he testified?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Mr. Corbett you mean?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: He testified that he offered him -- he said that he --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did he say Mr. Corbett advised him that he was being held against his will, he was entitled to seek a writ of habeas corpus and advised those agent would furnish him counsel.
Mr. Corbett testified, he said he was not held against his will.
He wanted to help the police solve the murder.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: They told him they bar association would furnish him counsel but he said he did not want to leave the jail or the hospital whichever place he might be.
Is that the testimony?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: He -- I think that is Mr. Corbett's testimony.
Yes.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: He has disputed it?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, Mr. --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: What was (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: What is it?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Except now, that was disputed (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Well, that's disputed.
Now, Mr. Triplett says he doesn't remember saying that to Mr. Corbett or Mr. Corbett saying that to him.
But he also says that he was under this fear of mob violence and that is not disputed in the record.
Now, the question in my mind is, Your Honor.
Could these people, even Mr. Corbett, and could these detectives set themselves up as magistrates and decide whether or not this man wanted a lawyer.
His rights to due process would be to take him before a magistrate where all his rights would be explained to him by a magistrate not by some president or some bar association.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The source of my curiosity is that, that what actually the details of Mr. Corbett's testimony, as in for the minute.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They shed light on the conditions under which the petitioner was then and confined.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I didn't mean to suggest that he could be a private judiciary and I don't think there's any such suggestion.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: What charge was he arraigned on?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: He was arraigned on first degree murder.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: You mean that say, he was arraigned, and to what charge (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Well, they arrested him for the -- evidently for the murder of Jimmy Bremmers.
So, they had to arrest him for it and he was taken in without a warrant.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, had the boy's body been found when Mr. -- the bar association president visited, Mr. Triplett?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: The -- the boy's body had been found I believe on the -- but Mr. Corbett didn't know about that at the time.
I don't believe that he knew.
I think the record will show that.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: When was the boy's body found with reference to the date of the arrest?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: The date of the arrest, well, it's found 29 days later.
Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's in --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: And now, the --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- about six days after Mr. Corbett saw him in the jail.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes, that's right and then they immediately took Mr. Triplett from the jail and took him out into the country where the boy's body was found and showed him a blanket covered body and -- and such as that.
Now, there is one thing I want to call the Court's attention to and I want to save a little of my time for rebuttal if necessary.

The reason they held this man is expressed in one sentence by William Dennison, the man who arrested him, and I asked him on cross-examination, “Why didn't you take this man before a magistrate as the law requires you to do before you got the confession instead of afterwards hold him in for some 20 days in the police custody?”
He said "Because I still thought he was guilty."
Now, they can say what the police about why they held him but that's the testimony of the chief detectives under whose custody was because he still thought he was guilty.
I'd like to save the rest of my time.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you're not -- your position isn't that the mere days of detention without arraignment violates -- is a deprivation --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- of the Fourteenth Amendment.
That's not your position.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: No, that is not, sir.

But the way that the confession was gotten in the insane hospital after he's committed there and Dr.Azordegan promised him a job at the hospital work to do and let him out in a couple of years if he confessed.
Now, that's uncontradicted in the record, we you understand.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What you're saying is the totality of the circumstance.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: That's right.
The whole totality of it, I think violates every concept of the due process of law.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: May I ask you?
What you claim about saying that is uncontradicted in the record.
Do you mean the testimony with respect to what the doctor said --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: -- in at the hospital.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: That's right.
The doctor was not available for some reason.
They gave a lot of reasons but they didn't -- it was all hearsay.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Of course --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What is it hearsay that he was physically unavailable?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: They said -- no, they didn't say that by direct testimony.
They asked Bill Sanguin who was a -- a tenant at the hospital where Dr. Azordegan was and he said he heard a report that he was overseas.
Then they asked the accused himself on cross examination, “Haven't you been advised that Dr.Azordegan is overseas?”
and Triplett answered, “No, I haven't been advised.
I heard it a minute ago."
Now, there's all we got in there.
They didn't call the superintendent to know why there was two doctors left at the hospital right after this thing happened.
This confession taken in the hospital was taken without the knowledge or consent of the superintendent by the way.
And we have our suspicion --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Was that recorded?
It was a tape recording, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes, sir.
A tape recording.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Where -- where is the -- where is it in the record?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: It's on page -- in -- in the record, the -- that's the page -- the confession 40 -- 40 to 49.
Yes, I'd like to save a little of my time.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You may -- you may Mr. --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: How much time do I have, Chief Justice, do you know?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Do you know how much time I have?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The clerk will advise you with it.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes, all right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Forrest.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Chief Justice, Associate Justices, may it please the Court.
This Court has recently interested itself in a number of cases similar to the one now before it.

The gist of these cases, that is those cases which pertain to state criminal prosecutions, has been to determine -- for this Court to determine whether or not and a confession obtained in the period of custody was obtained in such a manner as to violate the -- the petitioners or the defendants rights under the Fourteenth Amendment, that is whether or not the -- the confession was obtained by physical or mental coercion.
The test as recently reaffirmed in the Payne case on Monday remains.
It's the contrasting of the pressures that are applied to the person confessing as opposed to his power to resist.
That question as pointed out by the respondents certainly can -- or by the petitioner can certainly best be answered by a close examination into the facts.

I'd like to talk first about the general fact background and later, more particularly about some of the specific testimony given by both police officers, the trial court and specially the defendant himself.
The general facts in chronological order went about as follows.
On August 31, the lad disappeared.
At that time, the defendant was employed as a door-to-door solicitor and salesman on behalf of the Flood Music Company in Sioux City.
He was operating in the neighborhood in which the boy lived and from which he disappeared on the day that he did disappear.
When the disappearance of the boy became generally known, a search was instituted.
Also, word was passed to the police, to the Sioux City Police and thereupon on September 2nd, took him to the police station.
Shortly after he got to the police station, a private detective in Sioux City by the name of Matousec appeared and asked for a permission to question Triplett.
This was granted and there is no showing in the record that he was kept or in any way, inhibited from seeing the defendant.

Matousec's testimony was that he attempted to elicit information as to the crime by suggesting to the defendant that he would procure counsel for him, and this is substantiated by the defendant's testimony.
At that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Isn't it before he was taken into custody, Mr. Forrest?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: No, sir.
This was -- this was immediately after he was taken.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: The first few days after he was taken into custody.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: I am sorry that I do not enjoy the same circumstance as the petitioner for the -- that the petitioner's counsel does and that he tried the case in the lower court and I did not get it until it came to the United States Supreme Court.
But I'm -- I feel confident that the record will bare -- bare out that in the first few days of his custody, he was approached by Matousec and refused Matousec's in effect offer of counsel.
On September 15th, he volunteered to go to and was taken to the Cherokee Mental Health Institute for observation.
This is the wording of the record, “For observation and treatment of syphilis.”

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Can you tell me what -- why has he gone to the mental health institute?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: This is a question I cannot answer, Justice.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: So they're frequently -- it affects the mind.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The disease, they've had it suspected with that theoretically affecting his mind?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Perhaps it may have, Justice Black.
And I do not -- I just don't know.
I'm not that well acquainted with the trial court situation which was in 1954.
While there, the body of Jimmy Bremmers was located.
The defendant was brought back from the mental health institute, taken to a place on the highway adjacent to the field in which the body lay.
The roadway there is considerably below the --it's -- in other words, it's a cut in a hill.
The defendant without instructions from anyone walked diagonally directly up bank.
I believe he went across to a point outside the fence, pointed to the body and said, what is that?
There was some evidence that he turned pale at the time that he did that.
After he viewed the body, he was returned to the Sioux City Police Station, kept there for a few more days.
It was at this time that the visit of the then Sioux City Bar Association President Stanley Corbett took place.
Mr. Corbett came in, asked to see the defendant.
Again, there was no inhibition.
He was allowed to see him.
And at that time, he -- in substance, what he asked him was, "Are you being held against your will?"
And he said, he was not being held against his will because he wanted to help the police solve the murder.
He was also asked or offered counsel to take his choice of counsel in the Sioux City area.
This, he steadfastly refused as he had done previously.
I should probably point out also that detective Dennison testified that on numerous occasions, three or four times in the period between 2 and 15th of September.
The first period of incarceration or custody that he asked him about -- if he wanted an attorney and he steadfastly refused the services of an attorney.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How old a man was Triplett?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: I'm -- thank you.
Counsel for petitioner informs me that he was 52.
I was going to say that I'm sure that he was middle-aged.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In reading the confession, the language seems to be a little confusing.
What's your response to that?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: I don't know in what you mean -- in what way do you mean it's peculiar, Justice?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, the way the questions were asked.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Well, of course, Azordegan, the doctor, the psychiatrist to obtain the confession was an Iranian.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I see.
He was -- he didn't speak English well.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Not very well.
No, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And was he a psychiatrist?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Was he sent to the psychiatrist from the beginning, Triplett?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: From the beginning of his --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When they sent him to the hospital, did they send him to the psychiatrist?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Well, I -- I do not know the answer to that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It is a mental hospital?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: This was a mental hospital.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.
He was in a mental hospital.
Azordegan was a staff psychiatrist --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: This man -- this particularly was a psychiatrist.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.
Corbett's testimony was that he was not being held against his will and that he steadfastly refused the offer of services of counsel in the Sioux City area.
The defendant then was returned again at his own request to the Cherokee Institution, the mental health institute, and it was on this period that the confession was obtained.
As near as I can gather from what is in the record, what happened was that the mental institute people who help people down there called the Sioux City Police, had them come down.
They test -- the Sioux City Police testified that they did not know a confession was to be gotten that afternoon.
When they got there, they were taken in a room, there were three or four police -- two -- two police officers present.
Azordegan, the psychiatrist, who -- whose voice you will hear on Exhibit P which is with the Court.

The -- of course the petitioner and one Bill saying when a staff -- a member of the staff at the mental health institute who operated the tape recording machine.He made his confession and the trial was then had on the merits.
Now, since that --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Forrest there were --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- there were some statements made by counsel to the effect that a detective told him that it wouldn't be well for him to get out that the -- the crowd might do something to him.
Do you -- do you -- would you mind giving us your recollection of that phase of the case?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: The State's reaction to that, you realize that -- that this is uncorroborated testimony on the part of the defendant.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I don't know what it is at all, would you tell me your -- your version of that.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: The -- the defended himself, when he took the stand insisted that one of the police officers told him, I believe it was one of the police officers, told him that -- inferred to him, I don't think the language is exactly mob actions but inferred to him that if he got out of the police station, there would be dire consequences.
Now, in connection with that I intended to take it up a little later but I'll take it up --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, no, no.
Take it up in your own time please.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Well, I'll just have to deal with it right now, Justice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Anytime.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: The --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Well, on the one hand, that points again to the volunteer nature of his custody and on the other hand, Mr. Gibbons was certainly available to the petitioner for cross-examination.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But what do you mean that -- what do you mean?
Did the -- did the State put him on and have him deny it?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: The State did not do that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How could he cross examine him?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Was the statement made, I guess, the statement was made subsequent to -- well, they could have -- surely, he could have been recalled.
Well, I'd like to concede that point.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.
Proceed.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Can you -- can you give the dates between Mr. Corbett's visit and the testimony which has just been referred to, Mr. Corbett?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Mr. Corbett's visit took place on October 1.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what -- all right.
And this was -- Mr. Corbett testified as to his talk with the petitioner --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- as of October 1?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There were two talks as I looked at the stenographic minutes.
Mr. Corbett had two -- two interviews according to the minutes.
He was recalled, he was put on the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Oh yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, whenever that was.
You could say that's October 1st, and when was the trial, the date of the trial?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: I would have to refer to counsel for the petition.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would you care to do that.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: I'll state that.
That the trial was held the 30th in June.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The next year -- the next year?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: The next year of this confession of the statement, October.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: The man was arrested in January and the trial held the next June 6th.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Now, since the test as to whether or not this, the confession that was admitted for the evidence violates the petitioner's rights under the Fourteenth Amendment is whether -- is -- involves looking at the pressures that were applied to him with respect to his ability to withstand those pressures.

I would like to go at -- into some detail into the facts which -- most of which I have set out on pages 4, 5 and 6 I believe of -- well 4 through 10 of the State's brief beginning with Police Officer Dennison.
He testified that Mr. Triplett wasn't kept when he was in custody.
He slept regularly, was not interviewed for any sustained period of time that he said, quote, "I want to go along with you boys, I want to cooperate with you."
That Triplett volunteered to go to the Mental Health Instituted Charity.
Now, the volunteering on those things I think is better brought out by the fact that the petitioner does not contend that he was in custody any of the time that he was in the mental health institute.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why does he content that he went to the hospital?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: I don't think there's a contention by the -- by the petitioner as to why he went there.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And you think the statement to which --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: The State contends that he went there voluntarily, that they offered to take him there.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No, taking that for what?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: For the -- the purposes of --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The treatment of a venereal disease?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And was there another hospital in town where they had doctors who treated venereal diseases?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Well, I'm sure that there would be.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What -- is there any explanation as to why they took him to these particular place (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: The only -- the only explanation that I can offer to you, Justices, that which appears in the petitioner's brief.
He makes a reference to a petition -- petition for insanity against the petitioner.
Is that not correct, Mr. Tacy?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: He alludes to some civil procedure taken prior to trial.
There is no further reference to it in the petitioner's brief.
There is no reference to it in the trial court record.
I think I should also point out this.

That under the Iowa statute, I believe it's 783.3, the Court is required to stop the trial and have a trial on the insanity issue if any evidence is presented to it either on its own motion or on the part of either party as to insanity of the defendant.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there anything --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: This was not done.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there anything in the record which refused the statement of the petitioner attributed to him by Mr. Corbett who said that he was willing to go to the hospital and helped them all he could.
He went there because they -- they asked him to go and offered to give him treatment for his venereal disease which he had.
He went there for that purpose and was treated and was going back and they had said they'll treat him again for the venereal disease.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Now, your question?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there anything in the record which refused that statement made by the defendant to Mr. Corbett.

Does the record show as you read it that he was led to believe that he was sent to that hospital, at the mental hospital, for the treatment of his venereal disease from which he was then accused the suspect?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Well, certainly, it does show that whether it shows that he was sent there for other reasons, I don't think so, specially in view of the counsel's statement that the petitioner [Laughs] there to go down there because he would rather sleep on a mattress than on the steel bed that was given to him in the Sioux City, which incidentally the record shows he was given a mattress after a few days.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But it's rather the fields of my way of thinking and the reason I ask you, the theory from my way of thinking, that they send a man telling him they're going to treat him for venereal disease and send him to a psychiatrist, well there, gets the confession from him.
Is there anything to refuse the idea that that's what happened?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: I think that he knew he was going there for observation as well as --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: The observation of what?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Presumably homosexual tendencies.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, is there anything in the record that shows that?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: No, sir.
I wish there were.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Does Iowa have a statute for treating a sexual-type offenses?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is this the institution?
Is this the state institutional integrity?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, is very -- to treat venereal diagnosis whatever it may be, is that where it's treated?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: It is one of those institutions where that treatment and diagnosis may be made.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: There are more than one?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: I mean, how -- how -- Is it on voluntary commission as the --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: The State contends that this was voluntarily on the basis --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What's -- what's the statute that would handle voluntary commission or is there some system for involuntary commission for treatment --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Well, we have both.
The Court may -- there -- there are civil proceedings, there are -- there are summary proceedings by a Court in a criminal case and there are -- in other words, he can be both --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, is there anything in this record to indicate that this commitment was for that purpose whether voluntary or involuntary other than what Mr. Justice Black has referred to?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: No, I think not.
I think the -- the only statement that he was sent there for observation and treatment of syphilis.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where is the statement he was sent there for observation?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: I don't think I can put my finger on it this minute if --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: As to that, maybe your associate can find it.
I'd rather (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Forrest, you -- you said he went -- when he went to the hospital, he went there of his own free choice.

Now, when you say choice, do you mean the choice between staying in jail or going to the hospital, or do you mean the choice between going to the hospital and having his free will?Does the record show which -- which kind of a choice he had?
I just want it because it could be one thing if they -- if he could have his freedom and -- or go to the hospital be quite another.
If -- if his only choice was between sleeping in a cell on -- on an iron bed or going to -- to a hospital or he could sleep in a -- in a regular bed.
Now, does the record show what kind of a choice he was given?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Perhaps I should first point out that the record shows that he got a mattress after a few days.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I beg your pardon.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: I'd say perhaps I should first point out that he -- the record shows he did get a mattress after a few days but be that as it may.
The only thing in the record without going outside the record are the implications to be -- to be taken from the record.
In other words the petitioner makes no allegation to that effect.
The fact that the trial court did not stop the trial and hold a criminal proceeding.
Do I -- if I understood your question correctly --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I don't think -- I don't think so because you're not answering it.
You -- you told us that during -- during the time he was under arrest --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- or before arraignment that he went twice to the state hospital.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: This is true.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You told us also that he went there of his own choice.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, I asked you what choice he exercised.

Did he exercise the choice just between remaining in a -- in a cell under arrest where he had to sleep on an iron bed or go to the hospital or did he have his choice of going to the hospital or having his freedom?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: I think he had his choice of going to the hospital, certainly.
Whether he had his choice of freedom, I am not certain.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, as -- a choice has got to be between two things at least, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Well, of course our contention is --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is the choice --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: -- that -- that his choice was also that he stay in prison.
That's what he asked to do.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right, then -- then we get at this way then.
Do you -- is it your position that he was not under restraint when he was in the jail?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Well, if I answer yes to that, I have nothing in the record to substantiate me except the implication, the necessary implication.

The record and the fact that the petitioner insist that he was held 20 days, well of course, the actual period of custody was even longer than 20 days when you add in those periods of custody if you want to call it that in the mental health institute.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: He does not choose to add those periods.
I think that's --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: -- indicative of the fact that he had a choice whether he was going down there and that he did not contend that he was at that time in custody.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, let me ask you this.
Was the defendant under arrest at that time?
When he took him to the jail, was he under arrest?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.
How long did he remain under arrest before he -- he went -- was taken for a magistrate?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Well, 20 days.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was -- was the -- did he go before a magistrate 20 days after he was taken into custody?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: No, sir.
This is deducting --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right, all right.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: -- and -- and he -- he has deducted it himself.
He says (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I was not talking about him deducting and I'm talking about the -- the theory of the State in this --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- in this matter.
Was -- it's your position that he went to the -- to the hospital of his own free will.
When they finished with him at the hospital, was he operating under his own free will to go where he wanted?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: No, sir.
He was --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: He was taken under arrest?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And the same thing happened the second time.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, do you want us to conclude from that that he was not under arrest while he was in the hospital?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.
Where do you base it on in the record?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: The testimony to the effect that he volunteered to go there, the fact that he, in his own petition says, “I was held 14 days one time and six days the second,” and that's 20 days.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Didn't he say -- didn't he say though in the record that the reason he went there was because he'd rather have a decent place to sleep and sleep in a -- in a bed rather than in the cot or whatever it was, in the cell in the jail.
Wasn't that the reason he gave?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right, proceed then.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Dennison, Officer Dennison testified that when Triplett was in custody, he slept regularly, was not interviewed for any sustained period of time.
That he could not easily be led in the discussions in the questioning of him.
That he was of normal mentality.
Triplett -- that Triplett volunteered to go to the mental health institute for observation and treatment of syphilis, record page 97.
On three or four occasions, he asked Triplett if he wanted a lawyer and the defendant said he did not want any lawyer.
That there were never any promises or threats made.
That he did not expect a confession the day he went to the mental health institute.
During the time that he was in custody, his treatment generally speaking was good.
This was affirmed by the statement of Gibson -- of Harry -- of Chief Detective Harry Gibbons.

A Sioux City Bar Association President said in effect at Mr. Triplett, that he informed Mr. Triplett if he was being held against his will to seek a writ of habeas corpus and that he would give assistance of counsel for him, and that Triplett insisted that he did not want to leave the jail or the hospital whichever place he might be stating he had no other place to go and that he wanted to stay there and work for Mr. Gibbons in attempting to solve this murder.
Chief of Police Russell White testified that he was normal with respect to mentality and alertness and probably he's a harder person to interrogate as I have ever encountered.
He's very alert.
I don't think anybody during my time of being with him and listening to him ever was ahead of Erny Triplett on interrogation.
That he never made any promises or threats to the defendant and that no one did in his presence.
And that Triplett was of average intelligence, exceedingly alert and his mind was not easily led or swayed.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, wouldn't that indicate that there was no particular reason for taking him to a mental hospital for treatment?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.
The only other evidence that I know of is what the -- the petitioner has asserted that there was this other proceeding challenging the sanity of the man.
But he makes no further reference to it and there is none on the record as to the outcome of that proceeding.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did -- did he say that was during these -- these days or what he calls “unlawful detention”?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: He said that it followed immediately the visit of Corbett.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But he's been to the state hospital before that, hasn't he?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, why did they take him to a state hospital for?
I understood you to say that the inference -- there was -- in the record was, there's no testimony but there was an inference that they had sent him there not only for treatment for syphilis --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- but that it was also for -- for observation.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Testimony of Officer Dennison.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I -- I thought you just read us some testimony saying that there's no question about his mentality.
It was very clear, it was very sharp.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Well, of course.
I don't think that there is any necessarily correlation between his intelligence in the state of his sanity.
I mean, I think --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, what you said is -- I understood him to say his mind was very clear, very sharp.
And so -- well, that to me has something to do with a man's mental condition --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- if his mind is clear.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: But might -- but he might very well have a homosexual tendency without affecting the clearness of his mind.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well yes.I supposed that's true.
Well, what's in the record, you are going to point to something in the record for me, will you?
I -- I saw you look towards the record.
I thought you were going to --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- point out something.
All right, proceed.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Since I am so short on time, I want to go to the very heart of our argument.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Can I ask you one question?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is this mental hospital a state institution?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is there any other state institution in the vicinity there or non-mental hospital?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Is there a local hospital, county hospital or city hospital?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: City hospital.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In the city.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And this -- does this state hospital have something comparable to a prison ward or something like that on the security or --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Well, I'm sure it has a security ward.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, does it appear whether he was housed in the security ward?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: It -- it does not appear that he was housed in a security ward.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Does it appear where he was housed?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: No, sir.

You have considered a number of factors previously as the kind of pressure that when exerted on a certain personality, are sufficient to have violated the petitioner's rights under the Fourteenth Amendment.
Among those are age, comparative youth as you had in the Fikes case, education, you had in the Fikes case, mentality, you had in the Fikes case again.
But contrary to this, we have a 52-year old white man.
The Flood's testimony, that is, the people who employed him was that he was alert and active and a good salesman for them.
The testimony of the police was that he was alert.
Certainly his own testimony bears out the fact that he was articulate.
There is no problem on legality of arrest which you considered in Chambers versus Florida.
No problem on conditions of incarceration as in the Watts case.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, wait a minute.
No -- no question on the problem on -- on the --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: There is a question --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- and thus, if a man was arrested and held for 20 odd days without being taken to --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- a magistrate, there's no problem there.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: This is a question of delay of arraignment as in my classification.
In other words, the conditions at the time of his arrest were not violent in any way, shape or form.
That's what I meant to refer.
There was no period to prolong questioning.
Certainly, the record that the trial court made on page 16 verifies that there was no physical violence.
There was no deprivation of food and rest.
Triplett himself admitted he was given coffee and so forth.
There were no relays of long -- long relays of police officers, no emotional exhaustion that's shown in the record.
Triplett bragged about the fact that he was able to wear out the -- his questioners.
Counsel and friends were certainly admitted to see him.
He refused to take advantage or to use them in any way.
He was certainly --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Was that appeal affirmative of what you've just stated?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not questioning it.
I'm just pointing it out.

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: [laughs]
He was warned of his -- certainly, warned of his right to counsel.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But his friends were free to come and see him at anytime, you say?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: No, Matousec was allowed to walk in.
He was a completely disinterested person.
He was certainly not --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Matousec --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: He was -- witness Matousec was the private detective who visited him the first few days.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: In his custody?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Apparently, this -- he did this all on his own.
Didn't he, Matousec?

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes, sir.
He was subsequently employed by the defense counsel.
So that what we have is a lengthy delay.
The State does not -- does not deny that the delay was lengthy.
It does not deny that it was unlawful.
758.1 of the Colorado requires that he be taken forth with two magistrates.
What you have held in Stein, you have held in Alliance, that delay in arraignment alone is not sufficient.
That there must be something to -- to make a composite and we do not think the State's position is that there is no composite available here.
All there was, was the delay.
Additionally, we feel that the pressures that were exerted against this defendant as opposed to the kind of a defendant he was, and I do feel I must allude briefly to some of his testimony.

For example, “The only voluntary statement I made to seeing Jimmy Bremmers was that I -- that I saw some children playing in a nice yard but I thought one of them might have been him but I gave them a fabulous story on that.
I gave them a fabulous story on that other.”
Question, Mr. Triplett, “Do you have any reason why should -- why that you, under serious questioning for day after day that you were out rather easily?”
Answer, “Well, I wouldn't say that I wore out too easily.
I put a few of the big boys to sleep down there in the desk after I got on the desk.
After I got down to Cherokee, they appeared to take this tape recording.
I got the same amount of sleep there.”
“That's right, I'm denying everything I told the police.
Now if you want the truth, have doubts there.”
“Are you lying now or when you talked to the police?”
“I'm sworn in here.
You're not going to get me for perjury”.

We think that this shows the kind of a personality that it's going to take considerable pressure to be exerted on to take it to have deprived of him his -- of him -- him of his rights and we feel further that the only pressure that was exerted was this half-hearted almost voluntary custody of 20 days.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Tacy.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: May it please the Court.
If the Court's endowed about under what circumstances the accused went to Cherokee State Mental Hospital the first time on page 75 of the record.
Triplett was asked, it -- bottom of page 74 of the record.
“Did you not request to go to Cherokee Mental Hospital?”
He answers, “The request was made to Mr. Gibbons.”
Gibbons said, “I'll let you write the letter.”
He says, “You can or is your arm cramped this morning?
And I will tell you what to put in that letter.”
And he says, “Put it in there so, so at your own request, signed.”
“Would you call that your own request or would you call it the request of Mr. Gibbons?”
That's the circumstances on which you first went positive.
Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, the next question answered though?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, “Did you want to go to Cherokee?”
Answer, “Do I want to lay in a good bed or lay on steel.”

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is what he said to Mr. Corbett.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.
No, no, that's what he said to -- in cross-examination.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's -- I understand that --

turn.speaker: freeman_h_forrest
turn.label: Mr. Freeman H. Forrest
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- but that's what he says to the president of the bar association.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: You mean in their interchange by this --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: -- he said that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: You mean he said that in the interchange of conversation between him and Mr. Corbett.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.
Did he say that?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: No, he didn't say that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's my point.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: No, he didn't.
He said that -- that he hadn't done anything and he thought they were going to turn him loose.
That's his testimony.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, but as to why he went and his attitude towards his going to the Cherokee State Mental Hospital.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Well, Mr. Corbett --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)
Corbett.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Mr. Corbett came --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Not this that he wanted to lie in a better bed.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Now, Mr. Corbett came to see him after he's been in custody 29 days.
Then as soon as Mr. Corbett offered him assistance, and I draw an inference from this which possibly I am allowed to draw.

They took him -- according to the record here, they took him immediately to Sioux City before the Insane Commission and had him committed to the Cherokee State Mental Hospital for observation in what is known as the -- as the observation ward.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, you've just said something.
Is that in the record that he was before some -- some -- with some state procedure --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- if anything?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: That's right.
He --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Even then there's a best of reasons for having -- for having taken him to the Cherokee Hospital for mental diseases rather than some city hospital of ordinary general diseases.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.
Well, he -- he was -- he signed -- he signed an application that time that they request the officers, they put an X for him to sign and he signed it that he's inflicted with his -- he's inflicted --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Is that application in the record, Mr. Tacy?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: No, it is not in the record, sir.
This record is not too complete.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But it was shown in the record.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: What is it?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Of what you've just told us in that record.
They permitted him -- where is the evidence in the record?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: I -- I think, sir that that is -- if that is in the record that -- I think it's -- I think the State referred to that in their -- I believe in their -- they say -- they say as soon as Mr. Corbett's interview, he may say he was then taken to the State Mental Hospital.
That's all we have here.
That he was then taken.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you -- you've indicated a little while ago that --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- some procedure that for some presumably good reason, the authorities thought there ought to be some entirely be mistaken his -- into his mental health.
Isn't that what you said a minute ago?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes, I believe I did, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, was that before or after he first went to a mental hospital?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Now that -- the statement I made was when Corbett came to see him after 29 days of detention partly in the hospital and partly in the office of the -- or rather the police station in Sioux City.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, you mean he made -- he made -- these proceedings started after that?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: After Corbett visited.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Corbett visited him --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- 29 days after he was arrested.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.
And instead of giving Corbett time to do something, they took him right down there and the fourth day got this confession.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, but Corbett didn't go there to do something.
He went there --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: To find out.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- not what I've read in the testimony.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Evidently some -- if I may so, commendable members of the Sioux City Bar --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes, very much so.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They must present, I assume, there was alot about this in the newspapers.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And then some members of the Bar talked to their president, Mr. Corbett and said, “Well, this fellow, have we got lawyer for the other lawyer?”
And evidently induced Mr. Corbett to see him.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Not to offer himself as a lawyer he disavowed that completely and you accepted that disavowed.
What he said to the Bar, members of the Bar that he want a lawyer.
Isn't that right?
