turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: That is right, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And from all, not only the testimony but you're -- of what you think of Mr. Corbett, makes one attached verity to what he testified.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: I consider Mr. Corbett a very reputable member of the Bar.
His intentions were good.
But I say that when he had a suspicion that this man's rights were being invaded, due process denied him, I think it was his duty if he was going to give the man any advice.
I think it was his duty to tell the officers to arraign him right there.
There were some (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May I suggest that he replied to your questions by saying he concluded after talking with Triplett.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: On Triplett's statement that his rights were not being interfered with.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: He wasn't being held against his will.
That's -- yes, he concluded that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I mean, did you ask him that question?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes, sir.
And he --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And he has very clearly answered.
He says, “No, I didn't think that,” he didn't say there was a violation of disregarding the local statute of proper arraignment.”

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But he did not think that he's right.
So that is -- it isn't fair for us, I don't think we can infer that here is a friend of the Bar Association --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Oh, no.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- because I tried to open that it is the rights of the Board that were being violated and paid no attention to it.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: No, I don't think that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Isn't that what it seems to be the testimony.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: I don't -- I don't think that.
I would like to refer now briefly --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, may I ask.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, let me get the sequence in mind if I -- if I can?
Where -- where was Mr. Triplett when -- when this gentleman came to see him, the president of the bar association?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: He was in a jail cell.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: He was in his jail cell.
Had he ever been to the state hospital before that?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: He had been there on the 15th of September and stayed a little while.
That's the time that he said he wanted to -- he'd like to sleep on a better --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: -- bed.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: And then when Mr. Corbett interviewed him, it was 15 days later.
That is the 1st of October.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Then immediately, he was taken to the state hospital again to put through the screening center and to be examined, and then the fourth day now, after Mr. Corbett interviewed him, they had that confession out of him down there on the 6th of October.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.
Now, what I want to know is when -- when did this proceeding, legal proceeding and have him examined as his excite -- apparently whatever it was in that hospital admission.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Right after Corbett visited.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Right after Corbett visited.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: The State's brief -- the State's --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, isn't any of these in the record, Mr. Tacey?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes, it is in the record, sir.
I think I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I mean in the stenographic minutes?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: It's in the -- yes, it's in the stenographic minute.
It's in the reporter's transcript, certainly.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what I'm talking about.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Oh yes, that's all in the reporter's transcript.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You've got what we call Exhibits K and KI.
The State refers to that in page -- page where we would find --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: I think so, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- statement at the middle in his handwriting.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.
You will find all of that in the -- yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Exhibit K and KI --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- but I do not find them in the printed record.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: No, that's right.
And they are in the reporter's transcript which we called the -- the transcript of the record.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, let me get this clear if I may.
This -- is that -- is that K or whatever it is, is that an application which initiates a procedure under your State's sexual psychopath statute.
Is that it?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: No, it is not sir.
It is under -- it's under the regular insanity statute.
Just plain insanity, that's what it says.
That the -- the applicants or those who apply it for them is afflicted with insanity.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It has nothing to do with --

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: No.
Not with the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- being a sexual psychopath as such.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: No, and I -- I don't believe that sexual psychopathic statute in Iowa is very recent.
I don't know whether it's even as in existence and -- but there was nothing about that.
It was plain insanity.
Now, I want to say just -- if I can say one more word now.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You may.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: That here is a confession that was extorted from this man in an insane hospital when there had been no finding made as to why he was down there or whether he couldn't -- should have been sent down there and it as under circumstances that couldn't have been carried on in a court of law.
It wasn't a voluntary confession.
It was a grueling cross-examination by four different people.
One attendant in the hospital had him in charge, one detective and two doctors got part in it.
There was no voluntary expression on his part.
There's nothing that came from his own mind, he so testified.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, there's many -- it wouldn't make any difference to your -- that's a hypothetic question here.

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Suppose this is exactly the same confession, word per word, every other circumstance is saying had been made in a (Inaudible) mind local hospital rather than in Cherokee, would your position be any different?

turn.speaker: thomas_o_tacy
turn.label: Mr. Thomas O. Tacy
turn.text: Oh, I don't believe it would, sir.
I don't believe it would.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.
